prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. So the question is whether the author is in the wrong for telling their friend that her being single is because of having five kids with different fathers. 

First, I need to consider the context. The friend has been making a lot of insults towards the author for two years. The friend's comments are not just about their own situation but are personally attacking the author's appearance and work. The author kept brushing off the insults, trying to give advice like focusing on oneself. Then, when the friend asks again, the author responds by pointing out the friend's situation with the kids and child support as a reason for her difficulty in finding a partner.

The key here is whether the author's response was justified. The author felt insulted and was tired of being targeted, so they called out the friend's specific behavior. But does that make it okay to be honest in that way? Also, the mutual friends are now saying the author is privileged and doesn't understand what the friend is going through. 

From a social standpoint, even if the friend was making the author uncomfortable, the author's response might have been too direct and could come across as judgmental. The friend might have been in a vulnerable state, and pointing out her situation could have been hurtful, even if the author believed it was true. The friend's actions (divorces, single parenthood) don't necessarily define why she's having trouble finding a partner, but the author's statement assumes that this is the main issue. 

The author might not be in the wrong for standing up for themselves after being insulted, but the way they responded could have been more considerate. Maybe a better approach would have been to address the insults without attacking the friend's personal choices. The question is whether the author had the right to make such a personal comment in response. 

Also, the author's friend was already in a bad place, and the author's reply might have been the last straw. While the friend's behavior was unacceptable, the author's response could have been more constructive. So it's a mix of both. The author might not be entirely wrong for defending themselves, but the method could have been better. However, based on typical AITA standards, being direct and personal might be seen as the problem. So the answer might be A (Yes, the author is in the wrong) because even though the friend was being an ass, the author's response was unkind and possibly not the best way to handle it.
